Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 08:50PM muttnut wrote: I had a mastectomy 2 weeks ago, and implants put in at that time, knowing that I would be having chemo and probably radiation.  The plastic surgeon filled them a little bit when he put them in, and said he'd do a fill 3 weeks after surgery, and that he'd overfill them if I was to have radiation (which I will) because they tend to shrink a bit.  Then I'll have enough skin when I have reconstruction, and if there's any extra it can be trimmed away.  I'm planning on having the DIEP when I have reconstruction, unless I test positive for BRCA, in which case I guess I'd have another mastectomy and implants.
Posts.Title: expanders in and now have to have radiation demarini25 NancyD

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 02:45AM muttnut wrote: I talked to my PS last week, a highly recommended one at Mercy in Baltimore.  He even has the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval.  I had a unilateral in March, am doing chemo now, then radiation, then reconstruction with the DIEP.  The PS told me that the best reconstruction after radiation is one that uses your own tissue.  Implants can be a problem with radiated tissue.  He also said to wait at least 3-6 months after radiation before doing reconstruction to give the skin time to heal.  I am scheduled for surgery in May of '09.  I had thought I'd be able to have it just a few months after radiation, but then I heard about the 3-6 months, and the earliest I would have wanted it due to planned trips, etc. would have been March, so I guess it's not so bad.  At least I have my "boobette" until then!
Posts.Title: Rads + Reconstructon + Mastectomy joanne_elizabeth muttnut

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 09:27AM muttnut wrote: I had a mastectomy on 3/24, and don't remember waking up in the recovery room.  Last thing I remembered was being wheeled down the hall to surgery, then more wheeling down the hall, then in my room.  I spent the night in the hospital, and had problems with nausea.  I had told the anesthesiologist ahead of time that I got nausea from anesthesia, and he said he would add something to prevent it.  However, I woke up the day of surgery with a migraine, took Imitrex, but still had the migraine overnight after the surgery, so it might have been from that.  I threw up about every 2 hours during the night.  The nurses were wonderful.  They came within a minute every time I pushed the bell.  They gave me a couple of different meds for nausea. Finally something worked, and I was able to eat breakfast and keep it down.  I hadn't expected to go to the bathroom so much - I was on an IV until shortly before they let me go home.  I had to pee about every 2 hours, and it was pretty urgent.  I had some pain, but the nurses gave me pain pills every time I asked.  I had a tissue expander put in, and that was what hurt.  The incision has never hurt at all - actually the whole area is numb - maybe that's why there was no pain!
Posts.Title: Waking up after Surgery maryjaneFL SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 06:35AM muttnut wrote: Nancy, I'm about a week ahead of you in the process - had the core biopsy done last week, and it came back positive.  I had found 3 lumps in late December, after having been told my mammogram in August was find.  When I went for the core biopsy last Mon, the radiologist found 2 more.  She tested 4 of the 5, and 3 came back positive.  Met with the surgeon last week, scheduled for an MRI today, meet with the plastic surgeon and oncologist tomorrow. The core biopsy was OK - not as sore as I expected.  She gave me a numbing shot before each one.  I had to lie on my side with my arm over my head, and my arm went to sleep.  It wasn't pleasant, but not as bad as I'd expected.  They let me keep my sweater on over the gown I was given, so I wasn't cold.  Ice packs afterwards for 6 hours helped a lot - and it wasn't bad, because my breast stayed pretty numb, so the cold didn't really bother me.  I think it really helped with swelling and bruising.  I had little x tapes that were supposed to stay on for 5 days.  Good luck to you - I've heard plenty of women who got GOOD news after the core biopsy.  Hope you're one of them.
Posts.Title: Joining with a heavy heart NancyD hollyann

Posts.Content: muttnut wrote: My doctor said I am triple negative.  I assume this inclueds Her2?  I guess that's not good news, as it means fewer tools in the aresenal to fight it.  Also, what is an oncotype score? Life is uncertain - eat dessert first! Dx 2/19/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 3/13 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: triple negative, oncotype questions muttnut twink

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 05:15AM muttnut wrote: Hello, ladies.  I, too, will be starting chemo on the 16th of this month.  The original plan was to have sentinel node surgery, then chemo, then mastectomy and DIEP reconstruction at the same time.  Then, after the sentinel node biopsy (2 out of 5 positive) I got a call a week before I was to start chemo saying I should have the mastectomy first, so I had that 2 weeks ago, 1 more positive lymph node for a total of 3/13.  I will be having AC, every 2 weeks for 4 sessions, then T every 2 weeks for 4 sessions, then radiation, most likely for 6 weeks, and reconstruction some time after that.  Sigh...  I've already got my wig and an assortment of hats.  I figure once my hair starts to come out, I'm going to cut it 3 times at once to try a couple of new looks before shaving it off.  Might as well experiment when I have nothing to lose!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in April haykat57 angie27

Posts.Content: muttnut wrote: Hello, all.  I had a modified radical mastectomy on Monday, March 24, and a plastic surgeon put in a tissue expander to preserve the skin for when I have a DIEP reconstruction after chemo and radiation.  Spent the night in the hospital (definitely the right place to be - great nurses, they came promptly each time I buzzed when I threw up, needed pain meds, needed to go to the bathroom, etc.).  Came home on Tuesday.  I've been feeling pretty good, take the pain meds every 4 hours, am fairly comfortable.  I've started walking our 3 dogs again with either my husband or sister-in-law, and on Friday my sister-in-law and I went to the dog park.  My 25 lb dog was getting really nasty with a boxer, which didn't get the message to back off, so I lifted my 25 lb. dog to get her away before she instigated a fight.  I handed her off to my sister-in-law, and everything feels OK.  How bad is it to lift like that after a mastectomy?  I've just confessed to my husband, and will tell the doctor when I go on Monday, but I think I've escaped any reperucssions.  Anything I should be on the watch for?  I've just heard that someone else who had a double mastectomy was told not to lift PERIOD, for the rest of her life.  What is the reasoning for that????  Life is uncertain - eat dessert first! Dx 2/19/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 3/13 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: had surgery Monday - lifting??? muttnut muttnut

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 05:01AM muttnut wrote: I had 12 nodes removed - 3 positive.  My doctor doesn't seem concerned about lymphedema - told me that if I developed it, she'd send me to the lymphedema clinic.  Of course, she doesn't know yet that I picked up a 25 lb dog! I have an appointment with her later today, and will tell her then, and ask more about lymphedema.  I have a cousin in Denmark who had a mastectomy, and is in a group of Nordic walkers, who hike using their arms vigorously using walking sticks.  She said that research has shown that Norwegian women with breast cancer have a very low rate of lymphedema, and they think it is because they ski and use poles and their arms a lot.  Another friend says that in my area (DC region) there are crew teams of women who've had breast cancer who row on the Potomac every week.  One friend is supposed to wear a sleeve every time she flies to prevent lymphedema, but my doctor didn't recommend one.  It's confusing!
Posts.Title: had surgery Monday - lifting??? muttnut muttnut

Posts.Content: muttnut wrote: Hello, ladies, I have just been diagnosed with IDC (core biopsy) and have 4 tumors in my left breast.  The right is fine.  The game plan is/was to have sentinel node surgery first, followed by chemo, and then skin sparing mastectomy and DIEP reconstruction at the same time.  I had the sentinel node surgery yesterday, and the surgeon removed 5 lymph nodes.  I have hit the panic button thinking that she has to take out so many because she found cancer in at least 3, but my husband said she told him she didn't see anything abnormal and that they were tiny.  Could it be that different tumors would lead to different lymph nodes, and that's why she took so many?  I don't get the results back until next Tuesday.  I'm thinking that if there were so many because of malignancy that it will change the game plan and I'll have to have radiation, which would mean delayed reconstruction, and thus not a skin sparing mastectomy, either, which is really difficult.  I dread waking up with nothing there.  Anyone have any ideas about the lymph nodes, one way or another? Life is uncertain - eat dessert first! Dx 2/19/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 3/13 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: multiple tumors, 5 lymph nodes removed muttnut muttnut

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 06:38AM muttnut wrote: I just met with a genetic counselor on Friday, and am being tested.  She said that one of the BRCA genes causes increased risk of breast, ovarian and pancreatic cancer.  I can't remember which one.  She said the test is $3000, which my insurance company will pay.  She also said that if I test positive, they would know exactly which gene to look for, so my niece could have the test for that specific gene for $300.  I guess it's the difference between filtering for one gene vs. looking at all of them.  I'm praying I don't have the gene - my aunt died of ovarian cancer, and her son, my cousin, died of what might have been pancreatic cancer.  I need to talk to his sister to find out.  Needless to say, I'm worried!
Posts.Title: S.O.S. Request on BRAC Testing takingcare daughterofsurvivors

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 10:07AM muttnut wrote: My doctor used the 30 cc rule.  I had the first out after a week, but after 2 weeks, the 2nd was still putting out in the 55cc range, and my doctor took it out because at that point it had been in so long the risk of infection outweighed the benefit of the drain.  I'm SO glad to have both out!  I couldn't shower until the day after the 2nd one came out.  Feels so good to be clean!!!  Sponge baths just aren't the same!
Posts.Title: How Long Was Your Drainage Tube In? SueB46 Tina337

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 06:25AM muttnut wrote: Anne, you're right - adequate treatment trumps reconstruction.  My mind definitely was rushing to the dark corners.  I like your way with words!  From the comments posted, it sounds as if I don't need to worry as much as I was.  The doctor said she had to keep taking them until they showed clear, and my husband said she meant of the dye, which now makes more sense.  She also told him that nothing looked abnormal and that they were tiny, so I've got my fingers crossed.  The good news is that when the core biopsy was done the node that was sampled was clear.  This waiting for news is for the birds.  Thanks so much, everyone, for your support and feedback!  A community of women who've been through this is incredible support!
Posts.Title: multiple tumors, 5 lymph nodes removed muttnut muttnut

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 07:31PM muttnut wrote: I did pretty well through most of radiation, but did have some skin breakdown issues near the end.  My radiation oncologist gave me a prescription cream which helped, but it took forever to heal.  Once it started to heal, it healed really quickly.  I'd call the radiology office right away if there are any problems.  Also, the doctor told me not to use a washcloth, but one time I rubbed a bit too hard with my hand when I was peeling, and I think that started the skin breakdown.  When I was really peeling, the nurse told me to use hydrogen peroxide on a cotton ball a couple of times a day, and that bubbled a lot of the dead skin away without any rubbing, which helped.
Posts.Title: Radiation skin issues sillygirl16 sbruno3
